title: Soul Catcher-Merle Ricklefs Presentation-INDONESIAN
summary: This is my PowerPoint presentation on the pre-book launch of the Indonesian translation of Merle Ricklefs' 'Soul Catcher; Java's Fiery Prince Mangkunagara I, 1726-95' (Singapore: NUS Press, 2018), which will take place at the Universitas Kristen Satya Wacana on Thursday, 27 February 2020. Merle's book has been brilliantly rendered into Indonesian by the Universitas Negeri Yogyakarta (UNY), Muhamad Yuanda Zara, MA, PhD, with the title 'Samber Nyawa; Kisah Perjuangan Seorang Pahlawan Nasional Indonesia, Pangeran Mangkunegara I (1726-1795)'. It is due to be published by Penerbit Buku Kompas in April 2020, the 294th anniversary of MN I's birth (7 April 1726). Merle Ricklefs' writing of this full-length biography was the fulfilment of a long-cherished dream. In 1974, his biography of Yogyakarta's first sultan, Mangkubumi (r. 1749-92), had launched his academic career, and he closed it with the writing up of yet another biography, that of Mangkubumi's kinsman and quondam ally in the Giyanti Wars (1746-57), the remarkable eighteenth-century Javanese nobleman:  Raden Mas Said (Mangkunegoro I, 1726-95; r. 1757-95). Founder of the Mangkunegaran junior royal house in Surakarta in March 1757, this remarkable man, known for his diminutive stature, nimbleness of foot and piercing eyes, was a phenomenon. An accomplished warrior and military commander by the age of seventeen, he spent the next fourteen years of his young adult life (1743-1757) fighting, first in alliance with the Chinese and Madurese opponents of the VOC, then in fraught partnership (1746-53) with his uncle, Mangkubumi, and finally alone (1754-57), a feat of almost superhuman endurance. Such superhuman endurance was also the mark of Merle’s struggle as he battled ill-health to finish this book in the four years vouchsafed him between 2015 and 2019.

title: Jawasentris dalam Penulisan Sejarah Nasional Indonesia
Widjojo Koesoemo (Wijaya Kusuma) Between Tradition and Science, 1830 - 1939
summary: In the present Javanese society, the sacred flower Widjojo Koesoemo is considered to be a myth with no reference on the once-existed court tradition to obtain the flower for Javanese king. In this research, I demonstrate the role of Widjojo Koesoemo flower and the ritual mission to obtain the flower in the court of Surakarta during the Dutch colonial period. Based on Javanese manuscripts, the mission to obtain Widjojo Koesoemo flower was an important tradition and could be traced back from Javanese mythology as early as 12th century. In the 19th century, both the flower and the mission were needed to build the legitimacy of the king of Surakarta. After coronation of a king, the court of Surakarta dispatched a mission to obtain Widjojo Koesoemo flower. Two spiritual groups in the court: Juru suranata, the court ritual leader, and Reh Pangulon, the ulama’s body from the Great Mosque of Surakarta were sent to the sacred flower’s location at the Southeast Coast of Nusakambangan (Brambang) Island. Challenges to the secrecy of this flower appeared when the Dutch scientists from the second half of the 19th century onwards claimed to successfully demystify this flower by means of scientific explorations and then classified the flower into Linnaean taxonomy. I argue that the “silent rejection” of the court to any scientific claim is the evidence of Javanese cultural persistence. Besides, the Court still sent missions to the Southeast Coast of Nusakambangan until before 1945.  This tradition reflects that the king’s rightful ‘cultural’ authority over the kingdom of Surakarta remained unchanged in the period of the Dutch colonial supremacy.

title: Catatan Sebuah Peristiwa pada Masa Amangkurat I Dari Naskah Merapi-Merbabu
summary:
Gunung Merbabu yang dahulu dikenal dengan nama Damalung
atau Pamrihan merupakan pusat studi sastra dan agama Hindu-Budha,
tempat berlangsungnya tradisi penulisan dan penyalinan naskah-naskah
yang sekarang dikenal dengan naskah Merapi-Merbabu. Komunitas yang
tinggal di wilayah tersebut rupanya tidak menutup diri terhadap informasi dari luar, misalnya dari wilayah keraton. Hal ini dibuktikan dengan adanya beberapa naskah yang merekam peristiwa yang terjadi di keraton Mataram, khususnya pada masa Amangkurat I. Salah satunya berjudul Gita Sinangsaya. Rekaman peristiwa tidak terdapat dalam teks, melainkan dalam kolofon teks Gita Sinangsaya. Meskipun hanya merupakan catatan kecil, tetapi informasi ini sangat berarti karena ditulis bersamaan dengan peristiwa terjadi dan terutama karena catatan peristiwa ini tidak banyak disebutkan dalam teks-teks babad di lingkungan sastra Jawa. Artikel ini menganalisa kesejarahan sebuah laporan peristiwa dalam naskah Gita Sinangsaya yang terjadi pada sekitar tahun 1670 M berdasarkan informasi lain dalam babad
dan catatan Belanda.
Kata Kunci: Merapi-Merbabu, Gita Sinangsaya, Amangkurat I.

title: Sundberg_AdversityForRatuBokoMonks_2016_reduced.pdf
summary: A study of the Shaiva artifacts installed by the royal Sri Kumbhayoni around the Abhayagirin double-platform around A.D. 856, two years after the new Theravadin Lambakanna king Sena II had repudiated the primacy of the Abhayagiri and its doctrines, and about a year after the advent of a new king of Central Java.  It is argued that Kumbhayoni's supplements cannot be conceived as complementary to the Abhayagirin Buddhist mission, but rather must be seen as a repudiation of it.  The southern Ratu Boko as an abhisheka, perhaps rajyabhisheka, site is suggested.

title: The Kubrawī and Early Javanese Islam: Re-assessing the Significance of a 16th-century Kubrawī Silsila in the Sejarah Banten Ranté-Ranté
summary:
Beyond somewhat vague allusions to Sufi influence, a qualitative sense of early Javanese Islamic praxis remains sadly lacking among scholars. This article attempts to rectify that deficiency by re-assessing the importance of a Kubrawī silsila (spiritual genealogy) found within the 17th- to early 18th-century Javanese chronicle, Sejarah Banten Ranté-Ranté. First identified by Martin van Bruinessen in 1994, this silsila preserves detailed information about two separate Sunni-orientated Kubrawī lineages attributable to the latter’s Central Asian sub-branch, the
Hamadānī. Set within the context of other early Javanese Muslim texts containing previously overlooked evidence of Kubrawī praxis, in addition to hagiographical traditions identifying one Jumadil Kubra (a probable cypher for Kubrawī founder, Najm alDīn al-Kubrā) as the island’s earliest Muslim practitioner and a resident of Gresik, we argue that this silsila indicates considerable Kubrawī influence over Java’s initial Islamisation. Further consideration of the silsila’s specific Hamadānī characteristics set against wider 13th- to 15th-century Islamic history suggests either a north Indian or, more probably, Sino-Muslim origin for that influence. We therefore conclude by interpreting the Sejarah Banten silsila as a possible window onto the substantive nature of Sino-Muslim involvement in early Javanese Islam, adding further nuance to our understanding of that island’s Islamisation.

title: Foreword for 'Raffles dan Kita; Peringatan 200 Tahun The History of Java' [Raffles and We Indonesians; Memorial Volume for the Bicentennial of The History of Java]
summary: This is the Foreword I wrote to the bicentennial memorial volume edited by Catrini Kubontubuh and Eka Budianta, 'Raffles dan Kita; Peringatan 200 Tahun The History of Java' (Raffles and Us: Recollecting the Bicentennial of Raffles' History of Java [1817-2017]',  Jakarta: Badan Pelestarian Pusaka Indonesia / BPPI, 2017), pp.i-viii, which was published on 24 May 2017 to coincide with the 200th anniversary of the publication of Thomas Stamford Raffles famous, History of Java (1817). My foreword gives a critical appraisal of Raffles' record as a colonial administrator, and as a scholar and human being. It should be read in conjunction with my joint article with Roy Jordaan on '‘Thomas Stamford Raffles’ Masonic Career in Java: A New Perspective on the British Interregnum (1811-1816)’, JMBRAS [Journal of the Malaysian Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society], 90.2 no.313, pp,1-34, which has just been published by the Journal of the Malaysian Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society; and my chapter entitled 'The First Singaporean: Raffles - the Man and the Myth' which will be published in a joint volume of Raffles Bicentennial Conference Proceedings (Singapore: Asian Civilizations Museum, forthcoming March 2020, edited by  Stephen A. Murphy)

title: PERLAWANAN MASYARAKAT SAMIN TERHADAP KEBIJAKAN PAJAK PADA MASA KOLONIAL
Western civilization in Javanese vernacular: colonial education policy on Java 1800-1867
summary: Colonial education policy started much earlier than during the ethical policy of the early twentieth century. From the beginning of the nineteenth century onward we can discover that Western concepts based on the French and American revolution influenced Dutch colonial domination, which can be reflected in the earliest education policies up to 1867.

title: Madiun-Onghokham-PowerPoint-Feb 2018.pptx
summary: This was the PowerPoint I prepared for the relaunch of Indonesian historian, Dr Onghokham's, recently published 1975 Yale PhD Thesis on Madiun which came out in November 2018 under the title of "Madiun dalam Kemelut Sejarah: Priayi dan Petani di Keresidenan Madiun Abad XIX" (Madiun in the Vortex of History: Javanese Officials and Peasants in the Residency of Madiun in the Nineteenth Century" (Jakarta: Kepustakaan Populer Gramedia) and was reprinted in a second extensively revised edition in December 2019. The presentation of this second revised edition at which this PowerPoint presentation was given was held at the former pendapa (public reception pavilion) of the Kecamatan (sub-district) of Maospati in the kabupaten (district) of Magetan on Thursday, 12 December 2019, in the presence of an audience of nearly 300. The PowerPoint shows that Madiun has had a long and distinguished history many centuries before September 1948 when the Indonesian Communist Party Revolt occurred in Madiun, a tragic event which has sat like an incubus on Madiun history ever since.

title: Re-Estimating the Size of Javanese Jong Ship
summary:
It is known that the Javanese jong ship is larger than the Portuguese ships. There have been several scholars who have estimated the size of the jong ship, though in an unspecified manner. This study is intended to estimate the size of the jong ship by calculation. This paper explores historical records of jong sizes, claims of jong sizes, and calculates jong sizes with formulas according to shipbuilding rules. From the calculations carried out, the size of the Javanese jong is obtained. The results of this calculation reject and confirm the jong size research that has been done by other scholars, the claim that the jong can reach more than 300 m is rejected by the results of the calculations that have been carried out.
Diketahui bahwa kapal jong Jawa adalah kapal yang berukuran melebihi kapal Portugis. Sudah ada beberapa orang yang memperkirakan ukuran kapal jong, meskipun dengan cara yang tidak dirinci. Penelitian ini dimaksudkan memperkirakan ukuran kapal jong dengan cara perhitungan. Tulisan ini menelusuri catatan historis tentang ukuran jong, klaim ukuran jong, dan menghitung ukuran jong dengan rumus sesuai bidang perkapalan. Dari perhitungan yang dilakukan, ditemukan ukuran jong Jawa. Hasil dari perhitungan ini menolak dan mengkonfirmasi penelitian ukuran jong yang telah dilakukan sarjana lainnya, klaim bahwa jong dapat mencapai lebih dari 300 m ditolak dengan hasil perhitungan yang telah dilakukan.

title: Indonesian Communication System: The Myth Of The Prohibition Of Marriage Between Javanese And Sundanese
summary: This paper will review you about a popular myth that has grown over time in Indonesia, particularly in Java. It will analyze the historical background, the growing stereotypes in society, factors that inhibit cross-cultural communication and the best solution if it can reduce these barriers.

title: ECONOMIC POLITIC STRATEGY OF MANGKUNEGARA IV COLO MADU CANE SUGAR COMPANY CASE 1853-1881
summary:
ECONOMIC POLITIC STRATEGY OF MANGKUNEGARA IV
COLO MADU CANE SUGAR COMPANY CASE 1853-1881


Keyword : Mangkunegara IV, Colo Madu Cane Sugar Company, Leadership.

	Policy made by the ruler was an interesting topic in historical study. it because policies by the rulers influenced so many  aspect, for example land, labor and infestation. One of the implemented policies which the most interesting according the authors, is the strategy taken by Mangkunegara IV to founded Colomadu Sugar Mills. According to that previous statement, the author formulated three questions. First, what reason that made Mangkunagara founded sugar mills. Second, what is the implementation of this politic economic strategy of Mangkunagara. Thirdly, what is the impact of the operation of Colomadu sugar mill to business of Mangkunagara IV.  The object this research is to describe the motifs of Mangkunagara in case of Colomadu Sugar Mills. Secondly, this research try to understanding the politic-economic strategy of Mangkunagara and the impact of Colomadu Sugar mills to the others MangkuNagara business. 
This research took four steps, namely, collecting sources, criticizing, and presenting in written form.  The option for this topic based on reason that this theme never been wrote by others. Heuristic was a step of collecting information, for example archives, document and books that contain information of Mangkunagara. The next step is classified the sources, which include the primary and secondary sources. Critizing process was carried out in two steps. First step is external critic and second is internal critics. 
The finding of this study is that Praja Mangkunagara had the strong economic-politic based ion the reign of Mangkunagara IV. That conclusion proved by the operation of Colomadu Sugar factory that produce a lot advantage to the budget of praja Mangkunagara. This achievement was showed by the advanced of infrastructure and superstructure in Praja Mangkunagara. 
This can be concluded that the Mangkunagara Reign create the economical progress praja Mangkunagaran. The author suggest to the next study to focus on the developming of Factory administration.

title: Trilogi Madiun Raya Peluncuran Magetan 28 10 2021
summary: Pada 28 Oktober 2021 di Pendopo di Magetan Kepustakaan Populer Gramedia (KPG) meluncurkan dua buku tentang Madiun Raya (Madiun, Magetan, Ngawi, Ponorogo dan Pacitan) berjudul 'Antara Lawu dan Wilis: Arkeologi, Sejarah dan Legenda Madiun Raya Berdasarkan Catatan Lucien Adam [Residen Madiun 1934-38]' (ed. Christopher Reinhart) dan 'Kisah Brang Wetan: Berdasarkan Babad Alit dan Babade Nagara Patjitan' (terj. Karsono Hardjoseputro). Dua buku ini berupa bagian dari sebuah 'Trilogi Madiun Raya' dengan buku terakhir berjudul 'Bantheng Terakhir Yogykarta:Kisah Raden Ronggo Prawirodirjo III, Bupati Wedana Madiun, 1796-1810' oleh sejarawan muda Madiun, Akhlis Syamsal Qomar, menyusul pada bulan Maret 2022  Ini adalah PowerPoint yang saya mentontonkan saat peluncuran dua buku Trilogi Madiun di Pendopo Magetan. Semoga PowerPoint pendek ini bisa digunakan sebagai pengantar untuk dua buku awal 'Trilogi Madiun'.

title: The power of the heart that blazes in the world: an Islamic theory of religions in early modern Java [2019]
summary:
(Open access, see below.)
The prominence of Hindu-Buddhist mythology, imagery, and religiosity in Islamic Java has puzzled observers. The shadow play with its Mahābhārata- and Rāmāyaṇa-derived subject matter is a prime example. Another is the late 18th-century ‘renaissance’ of Old Javanese literature in the Islamic kingdom of Surakarta, which produced classics still celebrated today. Beyond a misguided assumption that the Javanese were so strongly disposed to syncretism that blatant doctrinal clashes did not bother their intellectuals, the factors that animated this enterprise remain obscure, despite its critical consequence for the development of Javanese religiosities. I scrutinize several unstudied manuscripts and piece together information from hitherto unconnected scholarship to try to understand these factors, with reference to pressing circumstances, living theories, as well as people who think, feel, and hope. First I examine Javanese theoretical ideas about the relationship between the Hindu-Buddhist and Islamic traditions and the connection between epic narratives and the present and future of Java. Against this background I consider the initiative, in 1778, to reinterpret the ancient epic heritage, beginning with the Arjunawiwāha (composed c. 1030). Focal points of interest in the Islamic hermeneutics of this poem were a quest for inner potency and the resulting external power of violence, knowledge and revelation, and future kingship.
